greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array: A(r,1) = A065621(r); for c > 1, A(r,c) = A048724(A(r,c-1)), read by descending antidiagonals as A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), etc.
comment: For all n >= 1, A277818 (= A268389(n)+1) gives the (one-based) index of the column where n is located in this array, while A268671(n) gives the (one-based) index of the row where it is on.
This array is obtained when one selects from A277320 the columns 1, 3, 5, 15, 17, 51, ..., i.e., those with an index A001317(k).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..3321; the first 81 antidiagonals of the array
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
formula: As a composition of other permutations:
example: The top left corner of the array:
program: (define (A277820bi row col) (if (= 1 col) (A065621 row) (A048724 (A277820bi row (- col 1)))))
xref: Column 1: A065621, column 2: A277823, column 3: A277825.
Other related tables or permutations: A277880, A277901.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 01 2016
